job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

job_title: Receptionist in New York, NY
pros: The only two pro's this job contributes are coming out stronger internally (due to the level of abuse you will receive from higher-ups and patients), and being able to add something else to your resume.
cons: This is an abusive workplace. You will be running your whole shift as the doctor makes the receptionists overbook so she can make more money. You will over-exhaust yourself here as the higher-ups don't actually care about you and WILL 100% take advantage of you. A break is not guaranteed and you will be blamed if the company makes less that month, even if it was not your fault. The doctor has favorites and you must be from Romania to even come close to that title. The patients will blame you, curse at you and yell at you because they'll think it's your fault for the 4+ hour long wait. Lastly, schedule yourself some time for a weekly breakdown in the bathroom.

job_title: College Assistant in New York, NY
pros: One positive about working at the Wellness and Counseling Center is you get to interact and work directly with the students.  This is especially helpful if you want to get into psychology or the medical field after college.  You learn to deal with the different behavioral and mental personalities of each student which gives you a lot hands on experience. You learn patience, and understanding.
cons: It's very stressful in that you never know what kind of day you're going to have.  You might work your butt off and get a bad review from the director anyway.  Quite frankly, you never know which personality you're going to work with. Some days are sporadic and some days are a breeze.  Most jobs on campus are laid back, but at the Wellness and Counseling Center you are expected to be on your toes all day.  The director does not want the Wellness and Counseling staff (2 different departments that work together) to befriend each other. If you become friends with the staff, you are good as gone.

review_title: Worst Educational Institution on Planet Earth
job_title: Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Friendly fellow faculty, good staff
cons: The leadership is awful. The president, provost, and deans could not care less about students and the faculty working under their supervision. (They'll make a show that they do. But they care about their own ends at the end of the day.) They get large salaries for doing little that actually benefits the state of education at their own institution and they seem to have forgotten that the primary function of the college is to be a place of learning. They did close to zero during the pandemic to help faculty carry out their responsibilities. They are now thrusting class sizes upon faculty and students that are double previous levels and basically triple what one would have at a well-managed college, all without taking any pay cut for their incompetence. Even other colleges within the City University of New York do not seem to have been hit as hard. I regret investing so much time and effort into this place while passing up better opportunities at other colleges, ones where they actually seem to care about student outcomes and actually seem to be concerned with burning out their faculty. The end result was that I was just exploited more.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good Health Care program for TA/RA
cons: too many students for under graduate courses

job_title: Orientation Leader in New York, NY
pros:
-Great coworkers, very friendly people, helped each other 
-Nice supervisors, they don't forget you after you leave
-Can be pretty fun interacting with incoming students
-Pretty active job, a lot of moving around, which I liked
-They feed you (breakfast and lunch)
-Got to go explore the school more and connect with certain staff, which can be useful as a student
-Heavy interaction with strangers got me out of my comfort zone and made me less shy
-Flexible schedule
cons:
Cons aren't serious at all:
-Had to stand for long periods sometimes, but never really noticed the pain since I was enjoying myself
-Low pay, but makes sense considering the job
-Had to sit through a day-long orientation EVERY semester, but they were always pretty fun and the atmosphere was laid back
-Work started really early, but I'm a morning person, so... 

Basically there were no real cons for me. Every "bad" thing about the job seemed to have a good part that just cancelled it out. And the atmosphere and co-workers in general made me enjoy coming to work. I just wrote some things that could be cons for others.

review_title: Good work for a overly complex system that gets in the way of getting things done
job_title: Chief Technician in New York, NY
pros: Helping educate young smart people. Often interesting and rewarding work. Generous holidays.
cons: Decisions on major policy changes and operations seem to be made by administrators from the 30,000 foot view who have no understanding of how work really gets done. There is a shadow IT department who helps students and faculty because the true IT department is understaffed. There is a shadow physical plant department that does work that they never get to or can't get to. The administration does not seem to recognize how things really run and just want to optimize space and personnel without a long term perspective on the results of their actions today.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros:
Professional and diverse
Students are willing to learn, compared to some other colleges around NY. Therefore teaching there is a bit more pleasant. 
As an adjunct I would say that salary is ok, if you are a graduate student.
No one bothers you about the way you teach or grade your students.
cons:
You are never sure of what, or even if, you are teaching next semester.
Sometimes it seems that the school system is set up so that student's needs come last, when they should come first.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: To teach a diverse group of students
cons:
I was forced to resign from a contracted teaching position in the MCA Department  for using the word "hood" (i.e., neighborhood) in a class. This common street term, which has NO adverse connotations was perceived by 3-4 students (out of 30) as a "micro-aggression" and reported me to the dept. chair, who forced me to resign using threats of future non-renewal of my contract. After I resigned, he did not renew my contract. 

I am a lifelong supporter of minority causes and have certificates, publications, and a work history to prove it.

In short, I was the victim of political correctness gone berserk.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: Working as a Adjunct Lecturer is an excellent opportunity to pursue your passion and establish strong academic relationships with students and faculty who are truly motivated and dedicated to their studies and work.
cons: While the hourly pay is generous, as an Adjunct it does not amount to much as the hours are low. It can be a lot of preparation and grading for a little amount of money.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: City/state position, protection of the Union (PSC-CUNY), reasonable benefits. Relatively flexible hours. Laboratories relatively well equipped. Administrative personnel nice and cooperative. Salary never paid late. If you work for the RIGHT boss you there are chances to be happy and to progress scientifically and professionally.
cons: Bosses not on the same page and bickering. No vision for research. Lack of scientific environment. If you work for the WRONG boss you there are chances to be miserable and will go absolutely nowhere scientifically and professionally.

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Working at the City University of New York has been an amazing experience for me. I am also a student at the University so the Union does provide tuition reimbursements which is amazing. Personally working in academia has been a very interesting experience all together, I have been at City University for 3 years now supporting the Humanities and Social Sciences departments and the relationships that I have built with professors and other facility members are incredible, it is quite the learning experience.
cons: City University of New York  can be a very comfortable environment hence making it easy to get trapped in the same position for years.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Supervisor was readily available, and not difficult to get in contact with. This close interaction with my supervisors has led to the benefit of my professional development. Also, the quality of my research was able to benefit from this intimacy.
cons: The admission criteria is low and so there are many students who are not well prepared for their studies. Department didn't even look at my GRE scores, and many of my peers would not survive at other schools.

review_title: Great co-workers and management but horriificly inneffecient due to it's bureaucratic form.
job_title: College Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Can meet a lot of different people of different backgrounds and ideas. My immediate supervisors and co-workers worked very well together and loved to hear new ideas to help the office. Their shared knowledge of how to navigate City College and CUNY made many ordeals a much cleaner mess and one step closer to informing the student, faculty, or staff what to do next.  The management is always open to questions and helping you succeed which is excellent feedback for those first learning the office world. There is a moderate level of professionalism with open friendliness invested in each other's well-being. I really appreciated the supportive effort especially when those peak-college events occur such as registration or graduation.
cons:
The CUNY system is big and easy to point out its holes. Sometimes it feels like your hands are tied when issues move out of the office and into the rest of City College or CUNY at large. Like a stereotyped bureaucracy, City College holds nothing back having feedback loops of people being sent to the wrong office and intentionally or not, ending up at our and the CAs or staff, helping them find the real answer to their needs.

Many times our office receives misinformation that only we notice, fix and notify the sender of, despite it being a major issue for the other office.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Everyone is very friendly and willing to teach and collaborate. A great environment to work and grow.
cons: The administrative system is a bit old fashion and bureaucracy, and people working there has a common view that nothing can be done to improve and avoid thinking about the problem, which might be a bit depressing.

review_title: Picture a Mix of Government and Corporate Administrative Environment with Great People

pros: Great place to work as an intern. Lots of hands on experience for people in the IT department. Got to go along with the technicians and watch them work. cons: No monetary compensation for people interning from outside CCNY, college policy. Other than that, the work environment/experience was very pleasant.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY

1, being a teacher in college means being respected.
2, you get to decide everything for the class, no one would yell at you or butt in

4, high pay, 68 ( if i remember right) USD for one  hour.

1, you need to spend more time on preperation and homework grading without getting paid.
2, being a teacher actually, how to say this, it would not bring you any acadamic bonus.

review_title: Pretty good place to be in Grad School with a few annoyances

cons: Hard to get teaching here if you are not grad student. As a postdoc I am not able to teach land anymore since the priority is given to the grad students.

review_title: good place to work. I like it because it's the place where I study.

cons: very strict on time sheet and students' log. sometimes, you don't really have anything to write about your students, but you have to write something

review_title: `Good Place to Work If you are tired of corporate organization
job_title: in Bronx, NY
pros: Summer is chill. Your busy one moment and then less bussy the next. This will depend on who your manager or boss is.
cons: You can be in the same poisition for the rest of your life, and earn the same amount forever. It's not advisable if you are looking to build a career

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: From what I can tell, CCNY was a decent school in the past. However, CCNY is no longer a good college. The New York City metropolitan area is nice. However, CCNY is located in Harlem which is not a nice part of Manhattan.
cons:
My experience teaching at City College of New York has been a nightmare. I do not recommend that anyone teach here. First of all, the students at CCNY are extremely poor academically. CCNY has a single digit 4 year graduation rate. Nearly everyone that I have spoken to at CCNY thinks that CCNY is a joke and a very terrible place and rightfully so.

The students and the administration at CCNY are very vicious and malicious. They will lie to you, offend you, intimidate you, sexually harass you, and creep you out. They hate you. The students have no problem screaming at me in the middle of class when I am trying to teach them. To make matters worse, when I talked to the administration about this deplorable behavior at CCNY, the administration at CCNY has responded by harassing me about the situation. The administration promotes this kind of behavior in class. It gets worse though. I had students make violent threats against me, and the administration has done nothing but harass me when students are making violent threats against me.

Most of the students at CCNY openly cheat and I am afraid to say anything about it because I know how the administration responds to cheating. The administration at CCNY turns a blind eye towards cheating because cheating is the only way for CCNY to improve its very low passing rates and its very low graduation rates.

The pay rate at CCNY is very bad especially for New York City. The classes are overcrowded. The facilities at CCNY are in disrepair because CCNY is a very cheap school. The wate at CCNY is very dirty and milky.

job_title: Lab Technician in New York, NY
pros: Campus environment in the city. -- Ok place for an undergrad education a few RO1's around, and the occasional kind professor. (Some of the affiliate departments are some what better, Math, physics, engineering)
cons:
Under funded, over administered, nasty politics. Not a Research School.
Many of the junior faculty seem to spend there time being offended that the school offers negligible support and requires a real teaching load. The senior faculty are still getting over the Idea of open admissions.
and a rotating chair.

review_title: Program Assistant , this was one of the best places I ever worked in this was a real family enviroment.
job_title: Program Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Learning more on how to help others while learning more on the fundamentals on Adult Education.
cons: You get really attached to the people you work with and it hurts when you have to leave.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Nice new facility to come out this spring. Very good nano-fabrication tools, friendly research environment. Very convenient life in the city, and very productive researchers.
cons: The neighborhood is not the safest place of the city. No work in the office or lab in the late night is recommended, which might be disturbing sometimes when catching up with some deadlines.

review_title: Great mission; great faculty; administration can be clueless
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The faculty and mid-level administrators really believe in CCNY's mission and offer great advice and go out of their way to help their students.
cons: Current administration seems to prefer an adversarial relationship with students and faculty. Departments are pitted against each other for limited resources and the administration plays favorites with programs and faculty relations.

review_title: Great experience, I wish salary could be adjusted to reflect amount of work.

cons: The salary should be a major focus instead of and after thought,

cons: Some of the supervisors are too strict, they dont even let you take a rest. They just keep you working and working.

review_title: Great sense of accomplishment for essentially pro bono work

job_title: College Assistant in New York, NY

cons: As a student  workers we only get less than 20 hours of work in a week.  To get all the benefits such as health insurance, dental and etc, we need 20 or more hours.

cons: A lot of the support staff at the university simply do not do they're charge and can be either very rude or non-responsive.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New York, NY

cons: Many of the upper division physical chemistry laboratory classes are very disorganized. Some professors do not take upper division laboratory lecture sessions seriously.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY

review_title: Only if you have a PhD.

pros: As long as you are competent, you'll go far.

review_title: The is a weird place to work for

review_title: Great overall experience. very friendly people

review_title: Great place to work and grow.
